column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=XIV .
#Text=WOLF

#Text=ON the anniversary of the night Mescal disappeared the mysterious voice which had called to Hare so often and so strangely again pierced his slumber , and brought him bolt upright in his bed shuddering and listening .
#Text=The dark room was as quiet as a tomb .
#Text=He fell back into his blankets trembling with emotion .
#Text=Sleep did not close his eyes again that night ; he lay in a fever waiting for the dawn , and when the gray gloom lightened he knew what he must do .
#Text=After breakfast he sought August Naab .
#Text=“ May I go across the river ? ” he asked .
#Text=The old man looked up from his carpenter 's task and fastened his glance on Hare .
#Text=“ Mescal ? ”
#Text=“ Yes . ”
#Text=“ I saw it long ago . ”
#Text=He shook his head and spread his great hands .
#Text=“ There 's no use for me to say what the desert is .
#Text=If you ever come back you 'll bring her .
#Text=Yes , you may go .
#Text=It 's a man 's deed .
#Text=God keep you ! ”

#Text=Hare spoke to no other person ; he filled one saddle-bag with grain , another with meat , bread , and dried fruits , strapped a five-gallon leather water-sack back of Silvermane 's saddle , and set out toward the river .
#Text=At the crossing-bar he removed Silvermane 's equipments and placed them in the boat .
#Text=At that moment a long howl , as of a dog baying the moon , startled him from his musings , and his eyes sought the river-bank , up and down , and then the opposite side .
#Text=An animal , which at first he took to be a gray timber-wolf , was running along the sand-bar of the landing .
#Text=“ Pretty white for a wolf , ” he muttered .
#Text=“ Might be a Navajo dog . ”
#Text=The beast sat down on his haunches and , lifting a lean head , sent up a doleful howl .
#Text=Then he began trotting along the bar , every few paces stepping to the edge of the water .
#Text=Presently he spied Hare , and he began to bark furiously .
#Text=“ It 's a dog all right ; wants to get across , ” said Hare .
#Text=“ Where have I seen him ? ”
#Text=Suddenly he sprang to his feet , almost upsetting the boat .
#Text=“ He 's like Mescal 's Wolf ! ”
#Text=He looked closer , his heart beginning to thump , and then he yelled : “ Ki-yi !
#Text=Wolf ! Hyer ! Hyer ! ”
#Text=The dog leaped straight up in the air , and coming down , began to dash back and forth along the sand with piercing yelps .
#Text=“ It 's Wolf !
#Text=Mescal must be near , ” cried Hare .
#Text=A veil obscured his sight , and every vein was like a hot cord .
#Text=“ Wolf !
#Text=Wolf !
#Text=I 'm coming ! ”
#Text=With trembling hands he tied Silvermane 's bridle to the stern seat of the boat and pushed off .
#Text=In his eagerness he rowed too hard , dragging Silvermane 's nose under water , and he had to check himself .
#Text=Time and again he turned to call to the dog .
#Text=At length the bow grated on the sand , and Silvermane emerged with a splash and a snort .
#Text=“ Wolf , old fellow ! ” cried Hare .
#Text=“ Where 's Mescal ?
#Text=Wolf , where is she ? ”
#Text=He threw his arms around the dog .
#Text=Wolf whined , licked Hare 's face , and breaking away , ran up the sandy trail , and back again .
#Text=But he barked no more ; he waited to see if Hare was following .
#Text=“ All right , Wolf -- coming . ”
#Text=Never had Hare saddled so speedily , nor mounted so quickly .
#Text=He sent Silvermane into the willow-skirted trail close behind the dog , up on the rocky bench , and then under the bulging wall .
#Text=Wolf reached the level between the canyon and Echo Cliffs , and then started straight west toward the Painted Desert .
#Text=He trotted a few rods and turned to see if the man was coming .
#Text=Doubt , fear , uncertainty ceased for Hare .
#Text=With the first blast of dust- scented air in his face he knew Wolf was leading him to Mescal .
#Text=He knew that the cry he had heard in his dream was hers , that the old mysterious promise of the desert had at last begun its fulfilment .
#Text=He gave one sharp exultant answer to that call .

#Text=The horizon , ever-widening , lay before him , and the treeless plains , the sun-scorched slopes , the sandy stretches , the massed blocks of black mesas , all seemed to welcome him ; his soul sang within him .
#Text=For Mescal was there .

#Text=Far away she must be , a mere grain of sand in all that world of drifting sands , perhaps ill , perhaps hurt , but alive , waiting for him , calling for him , crying out with a voice that no distance could silence .
#Text=He did not see the sharp peaks as pitiless barriers , nor the mesas and domes as black-faced death , nor the moisture-drinking sands as life-sucking foes to plant and beast and man .
#Text=That painted wonderland had sheltered Mescal for a year .
#Text=He had loved it for its color , its change , its secrecy ; he loved it now because it had not been a grave for Mescal , but a home .
#Text=Therefore he laughed at the deceiving yellow distances in the foreground of glistening mesas , at the deceiving purple distances of the far-off horizon .

#Text=The wind blew a song in his ears ; the dry desert odors were fragrance in his nostrils ; the sand tasted sweet between his teeth , and the quivering heat-waves , veiling the desert in transparent haze , framed beautiful pictures for his eyes .
#Text=Wolf kept to the fore for some thirty paces , and though he had ceased to stop , he still looked back to see if the horse and man were following .

#Text=Hare had noted the dog occasionally in the first hours of travel , but he had given his eyes mostly to the broken line of sky and desert in the west , to the receding contour of Echo Cliffs , to the spread and break of the desert near at hand .
#Text=Here and there life showed itself in a gaunt coyote sneaking into the cactus , or a horned toad huddling down in the dust , or a jewel-eyed lizard sunning himself upon a stone .
#Text=It was only when his excited fancy had cooled that Hare came to look closely at Wolf .
#Text=But for the dog 's color he could not have been distinguished from a real wolf .
#Text=His head and ears and tail drooped , and he was lame in his right front paw .
